properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm frigid grip on far Northern Ontario. After some moderation in temperatures and wind chills today, extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 will develop over portions of the area again tonight into Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T08:18:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T16:19:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3211499584.2019
Area: Peawanuck
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief but intense flurries, snow squalls and blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: generally near 5 cm, except locally 10 to 15 cm in some areas. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 50 to 80 km/h, strongest along the coast. Time Span: midday today until this evening. Locations: western Newfoundland. Remarks: An band of intense flurries will move into western Newfoundland from the Gulf of St. Lawrence around noon or early this afternoon. Winds will strengthen rapidly with the onset of the flurries, resulting in a period of very poor visibility in blowing snow. The flurries will become more intermittent this evening, but gusty winds will persist through the night with possible squalls and areas of blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-13T00:57:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T08:58:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3100682428.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to zero in blowing snow today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-12T22:00:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T12:21:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0540145144.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 today. Extreme cold wind chill values near or below minus 45 are may develop over portions of the area again tonight into Friday morning. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continuing this morning. These snow squalls are expected to weaken and move out of the area this morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible locally. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-12T20:07:18-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A general 10 to 15 cm snowfall on tap today into tonight. An Alberta clipper type of weather system will spread a large area of snow across parts of Northeastern Ontario today and tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected in many areas by the time the snow tapers off to a few flurries by Friday morning. Motorists should expect poor winter driving conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. These snowfall amounts are below the threshold of 15 cm per 12 hours required for snowfall warnings. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T08:33:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T16:34:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2717401684.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A frontal system is moving across the BC Interior today. Snow associated with this system will continue through this evening. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm is in the forecast with the heaviest amounts expected near Tumbler Ridge. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T09:40:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T17:41:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2865317222.2019
Area: B.C. South Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions with potentially damaging winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong ridge of high pressure is in place over the Northwest Territories. With low pressure over Alaska, strong winds with blowing snow are occurring over the northern sections of the Dempster. Near the Richardson Mountains, winds will reach 80 km/h gusting to 100 at times resulting in blizzard conditions. Blizzard conditions are forecast to improve this evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T06:01:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T16:31:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0540440398.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values are expected approach values near minus 50 tonight, and moderate again Friday afternoon. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T03:26:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T11:27:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3563468449.2019
Area: Yellowknife Region, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold arctic airmass is expected to remain in place throughout the remainder of this week and into mid next week. Wind chill values will moderate for most regions during the day, then once again fall into the minus 45 to 50 range overnight for the next several days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T08:42:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T16:43:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2763194323.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold arctic airmass is expected to remain in place throughout the week. Wind chills will moderate daily, before falling into the minus 40 to 50 range during the overnight to morning periods. Cloud cover to the south and west of High Level and Fort McMurray should keep the temperatures warmer and the wind chill above -40, but clear skies to the north and east of High Level and Fort McMurray will give much colder temperatures and wind chills. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T03:27:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T11:28:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1372331334.2019

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has developed, and is expected to remain until late morning or early afternoon on Thursday. The fog advisory may need to be expanded south and eastwards overnight as more fog develops. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-12T18:58:28-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Northerly winds with occasional gusts to 90 km/h have developed at Grise Fiord. These winds are expected to weaken later this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-12T23:53:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T12:54:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0683856599.2019
Area: Grise Fiord
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are possible today and tonight. Total snowfall: 5 cm except 10 in the heaviest flurries. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton and the Highlands. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Flurries will become more frequent today, with enhanced risk of snow squall activity developing as cold northwesterly winds prevail. In this case the blowing snow may be the main issue, resulting in poor visibility at times. Conditions will improve overnight into early Friday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T07:33:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T15:34:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3661180716.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Coldest wind chills: -45 to -40. Locations: Labrador City and Wabush. Time span: overnight tonight until early Friday morning. Remarks: Wind chill values will moderate somewhat today as temperatures rise, but conditions are expected to become extremely cold again overnight as temperatures fall below -30 with moderate winds. The frigid air mass will begin to slowly retreat from the region later Friday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-13T06:46:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T14:47:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1938020571.2019
Area: Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue this morning. Snow squalls will persist for areas east of Lake Superior this morning. An additional 10 to 15 cm of accumulation will be possible locally. Gusty winds will accompany these snow squalls at times, resulting in periods of blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 100 km/h. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: this afternoon until midnight tonight. Remarks: Flurries and occasional snow squalls will accompany the strong winds. Poor visibility in blowing snow will occur at times. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 20 cm is expected. A Pacific weather system is bringing snow to the southern highway passes. Over the Coquihalla Highway from Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, snow will continue today and tonight as the system passes through the region. The heavy snow will ease in intensity early Friday morning. Snow levels will remain near valley bottom except near Hope where rain is expected. Total snowfall amounts of 20 cm are expected before the snow tapers off early Friday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T09:36:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T17:37:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0354130921.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow squalls for tonight. A strong snow squall has developed over southern portions of Georgian Bay this evening. This intense squall is expected to persist through the night and produce locally significant snowfall amounts of up to 75 cm. Travel is expected to be difficult along portions of Highways 400 and 11 tonight due to heavy accumulating snow and near zero visibilities. The snow squalls are forecast to weaken by Thursday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-12T19:31:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T03:32:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3040691770.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall through the weekend 20 to 30 centimetres of snow are expected Saturday through Sunday. A low pressure system from the Southern United States will intensify before reaching the province on Saturday. An area of heavy snow will develop north of track. Quickly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values between -38 and -40 are expected overnight tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
